step_1: Update storage controller drivers from the motherboard or vendor website.
step_2: Check for firmware updates for NVMe/SSD from the drive manufacturer.
step_3: If using RAID, ensure the RAID controller firmware and drivers are current.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if issues started after an update.
step_5: Test the drive on another system to isolate driver vs hardware issues.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: NVMe firmware issue - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: After a crash I now see: NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM on my drive.
symptoms: Symptoms: NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: File System Corruption Errors.
cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: Large file copies failing — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: Large file copies failing. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Full / Low Storage Issues.
cause: Insufficient free space causing system and application failures.
step_1: Free up space by removing large unused files and emptying Recycle Bin.
step_2: Use Disk Cleanup and Storage Sense to remove temp and system files.
step_3: Move large media files to external storage to free C: space.
step_4: Uninstall unnecessary programs and clean application caches.
step_5: Consider upgrading to a larger drive or adding a secondary disk.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Large file copies failing - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: My system logs show: Stage 1/2/3 errors — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: Stage 1/2/3 errors. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: CHKDSK Errors.
cause: CHKDSK encountering deeper disk corruption or hardware issues preventing repairs.
step_1: Allow CHKDSK to complete; do not interrupt it while repairing.
step_2: If CHKDSK fails, note the stage and error and try running in WinPE environment.
step_3: Run SMART checks to determine if hardware is failing prior to further repairs.
step_4: Use specialized recovery tools (TestDisk, PhotoRec) if CHKDSK cannot repair files.
step_5: Replace failing drives and restore data from backups when necessary.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Stage 1/2/3 errors - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

cause: Insufficient free space causing system and application failures.
step_1: Free up space by removing large unused files and emptying Recycle Bin.

step_3: Move large media files to external storage to free C: space.

user_error_text: My system logs show: Disk freezing during large copies — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: Disk freezing during large copies. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Read/Write Failure.
cause: I/O errors due to failing drive, controller errors, or cable faults.
step_1: Attempt a file copy of small files to test read/write functionality.
step_2: Run `chkdsk` and SMART tests to identify I/O errors and bad sectors.
step_3: Check cables and ports for physical damage or loose connections.
step_4: Try using a different SATA/USB adapter or enclosure to rule out controller faults.
step_5: If unrecoverable, seek professional data recovery services.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Disk freezing during large copies - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).

user_error_text: My system logs show: Slow external HDD transfer speeds — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: Slow external HDD transfer speeds. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: External Drive & USB Storage Errors.
cause: Power or cable issues, faulty enclosure, or USB controller problems.
step_1: Try a different USB cable and port; prefer a powered USB port or hub.
step_2: Use a different enclosure/adapter to rule out faulty controller board.
step_3: Check whether the external drive gets power (LEDs/spinning sounds).
step_4: Safely eject and reconnect the drive; avoid force formatting.
step_5: If drive prompts format, use recovery tools to extract data before formatting.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Slow external HDD transfer speeds - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: My system logs show: SMART status: FAILING — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: SMART status: FAILING. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Bad Sectors / Physical Disk Damage.
cause: Physical damage to disk sectors or NAND cell wear causing read/write failures.
step_1: Backup any accessible data immediately to another drive.
step_2: Run SMART diagnostic tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to check reallocated/pending sectors.
step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: SMART status: FAILING - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

symptoms: Symptoms: RAW partition after crash. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Partition Table & Volume Errors.
cause: Partition table corruption or accidental deletion leading to inaccessible volumes.
step_1: Open Disk Management to check partition status and flags.
step_2: If partition is missing, use TestDisk to attempt partition table recovery.
step_3: Avoid writing to the disk until recovery completes to prevent overwriting data.
step_4: If recovery fails, consider a professional data recovery service.
step_5: After recovery, repartition and format the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.

cause: Loose cables, failed connectors, or controller issues preventing detection.

step_5: If not detected on multiple systems, the drive may be dead and require replacement.

user_error_text: Volume Boot Record corruption — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: Volume Boot Record corruption. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Boot Sector / MBR / GPT Errors.
cause: Damaged MBR/GPT or boot record preventing OS from finding boot files.
step_1: Boot from Windows installation media and choose Repair → Command Prompt.
step_2: Run: `bootrec /fixmbr`, `bootrec /fixboot`, `bootrec /scanos`, `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_3: If EFI partition is damaged, repair using `diskpart` and recreate the EFI partition as needed.
step_4: Verify BIOS/UEFI boot mode matches the partition table (MBR vs GPT).
step_5: If boot records cannot be restored, reinstall Windows after backing up data.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Volume Boot Record corruption - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Pending sector count high - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: I get: CHKDSK stuck and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: CHKDSK stuck. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: CHKDSK Errors.
cause: CHKDSK encountering deeper disk corruption or hardware issues preventing repairs.
step_1: Allow CHKDSK to complete; do not interrupt it while repairing.
step_2: If CHKDSK fails, note the stage and error and try running in WinPE environment.
step_3: Run SMART checks to determine if hardware is failing prior to further repairs.
step_4: Use specialized recovery tools (TestDisk, PhotoRec) if CHKDSK cannot repair files.
step_5: Replace failing drives and restore data from backups when necessary.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: CHKDSK stuck - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: Storage controller not loading appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: Storage controller not loading. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Storage Driver / Firmware Errors.
cause: Storage controller driver or firmware malfunction causing access errors.
step_1: Update storage controller drivers from the motherboard or vendor website.
step_2: Check for firmware updates for NVMe/SSD from the drive manufacturer.
step_3: If using RAID, ensure the RAID controller firmware and drivers are current.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if issues started after an update.
step_5: Test the drive on another system to isolate driver vs hardware issues.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Storage controller not loading - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

error_name: The disk structure is corrupted and unreadable
user_error_text: I get: The disk structure is corrupted and unreadable and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: The disk structure is corrupted and unreadable. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: File System Corruption Errors.
cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: The disk structure is corrupted and unreadable - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

symptoms: Symptoms: Power insufficient for external drive. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: External Drive & USB Storage Errors.
cause: Power or cable issues, faulty enclosure, or USB controller problems.
step_1: Try a different USB cable and port; prefer a powered USB port or hub.
step_2: Use a different enclosure/adapter to rule out faulty controller board.
step_3: Check whether the external drive gets power (LEDs/spinning sounds).
step_4: Safely eject and reconnect the drive; avoid force formatting.
step_5: If drive prompts format, use recovery tools to extract data before formatting.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Power insufficient for external drive - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: I get: Partition not accessible and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: Partition not accessible. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Partition Table & Volume Errors.
cause: Partition table corruption or accidental deletion leading to inaccessible volumes.
step_1: Open Disk Management to check partition status and flags.
step_2: If partition is missing, use TestDisk to attempt partition table recovery.
step_3: Avoid writing to the disk until recovery completes to prevent overwriting data.
step_4: If recovery fails, consider a professional data recovery service.
step_5: After recovery, repartition and format the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.

user_error_text: My system logs show: Volume Boot Record corruption — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: Volume Boot Record corruption. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Boot Sector / MBR / GPT Errors.
cause: Damaged MBR/GPT or boot record preventing OS from finding boot files.
step_1: Boot from Windows installation media and choose Repair → Command Prompt.
step_2: Run: `bootrec /fixmbr`, `bootrec /fixboot`, `bootrec /scanos`, `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_3: If EFI partition is damaged, repair using `diskpart` and recreate the EFI partition as needed.
step_4: Verify BIOS/UEFI boot mode matches the partition table (MBR vs GPT).
step_5: If boot records cannot be restored, reinstall Windows after backing up data.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Volume Boot Record corruption - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: NTFS_FILE_SYSTEM - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

error_name: Loose SATA cable causing detection failure
user_error_text: Loose SATA cable causing detection failure — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: Loose SATA cable causing detection failure. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Not Detected Errors.
cause: Loose cables, failed connectors, or controller issues preventing detection.
step_1: Power off and reseat SATA/M.2/USB cables and connectors.
step_2: Try connecting the drive to another port or PC to confirm detection.
step_3: Check BIOS/UEFI to see if drive appears at firmware level.
step_4: Update motherboard BIOS and storage controller drivers if applicable.
step_5: If not detected on multiple systems, the drive may be dead and require replacement.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Loose SATA cable causing detection failure - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: RAW partition after crash appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: RAW partition after crash. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Partition Table & Volume Errors.
cause: Partition table corruption or accidental deletion leading to inaccessible volumes.
step_1: Open Disk Management to check partition status and flags.
step_2: If partition is missing, use TestDisk to attempt partition table recovery.
step_3: Avoid writing to the disk until recovery completes to prevent overwriting data.
step_4: If recovery fails, consider a professional data recovery service.
step_5: After recovery, repartition and format the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: RAW partition after crash - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: File record segment unreadable — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: File record segment unreadable. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: File System Corruption Errors.
cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: File record segment unreadable - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: After a crash I now see: FAT_FILE_SYSTEM on my drive.
symptoms: Symptoms: FAT_FILE_SYSTEM. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: File System Corruption Errors.
cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: FAT_FILE_SYSTEM - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: My system logs show: Invalid boot sector — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: Invalid boot sector. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Boot Sector / MBR / GPT Errors.
cause: Damaged MBR/GPT or boot record preventing OS from finding boot files.
step_1: Boot from Windows installation media and choose Repair → Command Prompt.
step_2: Run: `bootrec /fixmbr`, `bootrec /fixboot`, `bootrec /scanos`, `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_3: If EFI partition is damaged, repair using `diskpart` and recreate the EFI partition as needed.
step_4: Verify BIOS/UEFI boot mode matches the partition table (MBR vs GPT).
step_5: If boot records cannot be restored, reinstall Windows after backing up data.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Invalid boot sector - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: After a crash I now see: NVMe firmware issue on my drive.
symptoms: Symptoms: NVMe firmware issue. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Storage Driver / Firmware Errors.
cause: Storage controller driver or firmware malfunction causing access errors.
step_1: Update storage controller drivers from the motherboard or vendor website.
step_2: Check for firmware updates for NVMe/SSD from the drive manufacturer.
step_3: If using RAID, ensure the RAID controller firmware and drivers are current.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if issues started after an update.
step_5: Test the drive on another system to isolate driver vs hardware issues.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: NVMe firmware issue - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: I get: SMART status: FAILING and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: SMART status: FAILING. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Bad Sectors / Physical Disk Damage.
cause: Physical damage to disk sectors or NAND cell wear causing read/write failures.
step_1: Backup any accessible data immediately to another drive.
step_2: Run SMART diagnostic tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to check reallocated/pending sectors.
step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: SMART status: FAILING - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

error_name: Windows detected problems with the file system
user_error_text: Windows detected problems with the file system appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: Windows detected problems with the file system. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: CHKDSK Errors.
cause: CHKDSK encountering deeper disk corruption or hardware issues preventing repairs.
step_1: Allow CHKDSK to complete; do not interrupt it while repairing.
step_2: If CHKDSK fails, note the stage and error and try running in WinPE environment.
step_3: Run SMART checks to determine if hardware is failing prior to further repairs.
step_4: Use specialized recovery tools (TestDisk, PhotoRec) if CHKDSK cannot repair files.
step_5: Replace failing drives and restore data from backups when necessary.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Windows detected problems with the file system - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

cause: I/O errors due to failing drive, controller errors, or cable faults.

user_error_text: After a crash I now see: Temp files filling the disk on my drive.
symptoms: Symptoms: Temp files filling the disk. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Full / Low Storage Issues.
cause: Insufficient free space causing system and application failures.
step_1: Free up space by removing large unused files and emptying Recycle Bin.
step_2: Use Disk Cleanup and Storage Sense to remove temp and system files.
step_3: Move large media files to external storage to free C: space.
step_4: Uninstall unnecessary programs and clean application caches.
step_5: Consider upgrading to a larger drive or adding a secondary disk.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Temp files filling the disk - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: Lost/Deleted partition appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: Lost/Deleted partition. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Partition Table & Volume Errors.
cause: Partition table corruption or accidental deletion leading to inaccessible volumes.
step_1: Open Disk Management to check partition status and flags.
step_2: If partition is missing, use TestDisk to attempt partition table recovery.
step_3: Avoid writing to the disk until recovery completes to prevent overwriting data.
step_4: If recovery fails, consider a professional data recovery service.
step_5: After recovery, repartition and format the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.

user_error_text: I get: MBR corrupted and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: MBR corrupted. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Boot Sector / MBR / GPT Errors.
cause: Damaged MBR/GPT or boot record preventing OS from finding boot files.
step_1: Boot from Windows installation media and choose Repair → Command Prompt.
step_2: Run: `bootrec /fixmbr`, `bootrec /fixboot`, `bootrec /scanos`, `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_3: If EFI partition is damaged, repair using `diskpart` and recreate the EFI partition as needed.
step_4: Verify BIOS/UEFI boot mode matches the partition table (MBR vs GPT).
step_5: If boot records cannot be restored, reinstall Windows after backing up data.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: MBR corrupted - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: CHKDSK stuck — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: CHKDSK stuck. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: CHKDSK Errors.
cause: CHKDSK encountering deeper disk corruption or hardware issues preventing repairs.
step_1: Allow CHKDSK to complete; do not interrupt it while repairing.
step_2: If CHKDSK fails, note the stage and error and try running in WinPE environment.
step_3: Run SMART checks to determine if hardware is failing prior to further repairs.
step_4: Use specialized recovery tools (TestDisk, PhotoRec) if CHKDSK cannot repair files.
step_5: Replace failing drives and restore data from backups when necessary.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: CHKDSK stuck - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: After a crash I now see: Read errors / write errors on my drive.
symptoms: Symptoms: Read errors / write errors. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Bad Sectors / Physical Disk Damage.
cause: Physical damage to disk sectors or NAND cell wear causing read/write failures.
step_1: Backup any accessible data immediately to another drive.
step_2: Run SMART diagnostic tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to check reallocated/pending sectors.
step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Read errors / write errors - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

symptoms: Symptoms: Drive not showing in Windows. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Not Detected Errors.
cause: Loose cables, failed connectors, or controller issues preventing detection.
step_1: Power off and reseat SATA/M.2/USB cables and connectors.
step_2: Try connecting the drive to another port or PC to confirm detection.
step_3: Check BIOS/UEFI to see if drive appears at firmware level.
step_4: Update motherboard BIOS and storage controller drivers if applicable.
step_5: If not detected on multiple systems, the drive may be dead and require replacement.

user_error_text: After a crash I now see: RAW file system detected on my drive.
symptoms: Symptoms: RAW file system detected. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: File System Corruption Errors.
cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: RAW file system detected - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

symptoms: Symptoms: INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Storage Driver / Firmware Errors.
cause: Storage controller driver or firmware malfunction causing access errors.
step_1: Update storage controller drivers from the motherboard or vendor website.
step_2: Check for firmware updates for NVMe/SSD from the drive manufacturer.
step_3: If using RAID, ensure the RAID controller firmware and drivers are current.

step_5: Test the drive on another system to isolate driver vs hardware issues.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.

step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: File record segment unreadable - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: Bad sectors found appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: Bad sectors found. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Bad Sectors / Physical Disk Damage.
cause: Physical damage to disk sectors or NAND cell wear causing read/write failures.
step_1: Backup any accessible data immediately to another drive.
step_2: Run SMART diagnostic tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to check reallocated/pending sectors.
step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Bad sectors found - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.

user_error_text: I get: Unrecoverable read error and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: Unrecoverable read error. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Read/Write Failure.
cause: I/O errors due to failing drive, controller errors, or cable faults.

user_error_text: I get: AHCI driver crash and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: AHCI driver crash. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Storage Driver / Firmware Errors.
cause: Storage controller driver or firmware malfunction causing access errors.
step_1: Update storage controller drivers from the motherboard or vendor website.
step_2: Check for firmware updates for NVMe/SSD from the drive manufacturer.
step_3: If using RAID, ensure the RAID controller firmware and drivers are current.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if issues started after an update.
step_5: Test the drive on another system to isolate driver vs hardware issues.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.

user_error_text: Invalid boot sector — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: Invalid boot sector. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Boot Sector / MBR / GPT Errors.
cause: Damaged MBR/GPT or boot record preventing OS from finding boot files.
step_1: Boot from Windows installation media and choose Repair → Command Prompt.
step_2: Run: `bootrec /fixmbr`, `bootrec /fixboot`, `bootrec /scanos`, `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_3: If EFI partition is damaged, repair using `diskpart` and recreate the EFI partition as needed.
step_4: Verify BIOS/UEFI boot mode matches the partition table (MBR vs GPT).
step_5: If boot records cannot be restored, reinstall Windows after backing up data.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Invalid boot sector - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: CHKDSK stuck — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: CHKDSK stuck. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: CHKDSK Errors.
cause: CHKDSK encountering deeper disk corruption or hardware issues preventing repairs.
step_1: Allow CHKDSK to complete; do not interrupt it while repairing.
step_2: If CHKDSK fails, note the stage and error and try running in WinPE environment.
step_3: Run SMART checks to determine if hardware is failing prior to further repairs.
step_4: Use specialized recovery tools (TestDisk, PhotoRec) if CHKDSK cannot repair files.
step_5: Replace failing drives and restore data from backups when necessary.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.

user_error_text: C drive full — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: C drive full. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Full / Low Storage Issues.
cause: Insufficient free space causing system and application failures.
step_1: Free up space by removing large unused files and emptying Recycle Bin.
step_2: Use Disk Cleanup and Storage Sense to remove temp and system files.
step_3: Move large media files to external storage to free C: space.
step_4: Uninstall unnecessary programs and clean application caches.
step_5: Consider upgrading to a larger drive or adding a secondary disk.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.

user_error_text: Partition not accessible appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: Partition not accessible. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Partition Table & Volume Errors.
cause: Partition table corruption or accidental deletion leading to inaccessible volumes.
step_1: Open Disk Management to check partition status and flags.
step_2: If partition is missing, use TestDisk to attempt partition table recovery.
step_3: Avoid writing to the disk until recovery completes to prevent overwriting data.
step_4: If recovery fails, consider a professional data recovery service.
step_5: After recovery, repartition and format the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Partition not accessible - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: External drive not mounting appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: External drive not mounting. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: External Drive & USB Storage Errors.
cause: Power or cable issues, faulty enclosure, or USB controller problems.
step_1: Try a different USB cable and port; prefer a powered USB port or hub.
step_2: Use a different enclosure/adapter to rule out faulty controller board.
step_3: Check whether the external drive gets power (LEDs/spinning sounds).
step_4: Safely eject and reconnect the drive; avoid force formatting.
step_5: If drive prompts format, use recovery tools to extract data before formatting.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: External drive not mounting - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: Operating System not found appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: Operating System not found. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Boot Sector / MBR / GPT Errors.
cause: Damaged MBR/GPT or boot record preventing OS from finding boot files.
step_1: Boot from Windows installation media and choose Repair → Command Prompt.
step_2: Run: `bootrec /fixmbr`, `bootrec /fixboot`, `bootrec /scanos`, `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_3: If EFI partition is damaged, repair using `diskpart` and recreate the EFI partition as needed.
step_4: Verify BIOS/UEFI boot mode matches the partition table (MBR vs GPT).
step_5: If boot records cannot be restored, reinstall Windows after backing up data.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Operating System not found - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

error_name: CHKDSK cannot continue in read-only mode
user_error_text: I get: CHKDSK cannot continue in read-only mode and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: CHKDSK cannot continue in read-only mode. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: CHKDSK Errors.
cause: CHKDSK encountering deeper disk corruption or hardware issues preventing repairs.
step_1: Allow CHKDSK to complete; do not interrupt it while repairing.
step_2: If CHKDSK fails, note the stage and error and try running in WinPE environment.
step_3: Run SMART checks to determine if hardware is failing prior to further repairs.
step_4: Use specialized recovery tools (TestDisk, PhotoRec) if CHKDSK cannot repair files.
step_5: Replace failing drives and restore data from backups when necessary.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: CHKDSK cannot continue in read-only mode - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: My system logs show: SMART status: FAILING — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: SMART status: FAILING. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Bad Sectors / Physical Disk Damage.
cause: Physical damage to disk sectors or NAND cell wear causing read/write failures.
step_1: Backup any accessible data immediately to another drive.
step_2: Run SMART diagnostic tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to check reallocated/pending sectors.
step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: SMART status: FAILING - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.

step_5: Test the drive on another system to isolate driver vs hardware issues.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: INACCESSIBLE_BOOT_DEVICE - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: File record segment unreadable appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: File record segment unreadable. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: File System Corruption Errors.
cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: File record segment unreadable - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: After a crash I now see: Drive shows 0 MB on my drive.
symptoms: Symptoms: Drive shows 0 MB. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Partition Table & Volume Errors.
cause: Partition table corruption or accidental deletion leading to inaccessible volumes.
step_1: Open Disk Management to check partition status and flags.
step_2: If partition is missing, use TestDisk to attempt partition table recovery.
step_3: Avoid writing to the disk until recovery completes to prevent overwriting data.
step_4: If recovery fails, consider a professional data recovery service.
step_5: After recovery, repartition and format the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Drive shows 0 MB - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: My system logs show: Bad sectors found — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: Bad sectors found. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Bad Sectors / Physical Disk Damage.
cause: Physical damage to disk sectors or NAND cell wear causing read/write failures.
step_1: Backup any accessible data immediately to another drive.
step_2: Run SMART diagnostic tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to check reallocated/pending sectors.
step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Bad sectors found - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: I get: External drive disconnects randomly and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: External drive disconnects randomly. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: External Drive & USB Storage Errors.
cause: Power or cable issues, faulty enclosure, or USB controller problems.
step_1: Try a different USB cable and port; prefer a powered USB port or hub.
step_2: Use a different enclosure/adapter to rule out faulty controller board.
step_3: Check whether the external drive gets power (LEDs/spinning sounds).
step_4: Safely eject and reconnect the drive; avoid force formatting.
step_5: If drive prompts format, use recovery tools to extract data before formatting.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: External drive disconnects randomly - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

error_name: CHKDSK cannot continue in read-only mode
user_error_text: CHKDSK cannot continue in read-only mode — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: CHKDSK cannot continue in read-only mode. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: CHKDSK Errors.
cause: CHKDSK encountering deeper disk corruption or hardware issues preventing repairs.
step_1: Allow CHKDSK to complete; do not interrupt it while repairing.
step_2: If CHKDSK fails, note the stage and error and try running in WinPE environment.
step_3: Run SMART checks to determine if hardware is failing prior to further repairs.
step_4: Use specialized recovery tools (TestDisk, PhotoRec) if CHKDSK cannot repair files.
step_5: Replace failing drives and restore data from backups when necessary.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: CHKDSK cannot continue in read-only mode - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: GPT partition corrupted — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: GPT partition corrupted. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Boot Sector / MBR / GPT Errors.
cause: Damaged MBR/GPT or boot record preventing OS from finding boot files.
step_1: Boot from Windows installation media and choose Repair → Command Prompt.
step_2: Run: `bootrec /fixmbr`, `bootrec /fixboot`, `bootrec /scanos`, `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_3: If EFI partition is damaged, repair using `diskpart` and recreate the EFI partition as needed.
step_4: Verify BIOS/UEFI boot mode matches the partition table (MBR vs GPT).
step_5: If boot records cannot be restored, reinstall Windows after backing up data.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: GPT partition corrupted - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

step_3: If using RAID, ensure the RAID controller firmware and drivers are current.
step_4: Roll back recent driver updates if issues started after an update.
step_5: Test the drive on another system to isolate driver vs hardware issues.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: USB storage driver corruption - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: Drive not showing in Windows — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: Drive not showing in Windows. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Not Detected Errors.
cause: Loose cables, failed connectors, or controller issues preventing detection.
step_1: Power off and reseat SATA/M.2/USB cables and connectors.
step_2: Try connecting the drive to another port or PC to confirm detection.
step_3: Check BIOS/UEFI to see if drive appears at firmware level.
step_4: Update motherboard BIOS and storage controller drivers if applicable.
step_5: If not detected on multiple systems, the drive may be dead and require replacement.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Drive not showing in Windows - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: CHKDSK stuck appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: CHKDSK stuck. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: CHKDSK Errors.
cause: CHKDSK encountering deeper disk corruption or hardware issues preventing repairs.
step_1: Allow CHKDSK to complete; do not interrupt it while repairing.
step_2: If CHKDSK fails, note the stage and error and try running in WinPE environment.
step_3: Run SMART checks to determine if hardware is failing prior to further repairs.
step_4: Use specialized recovery tools (TestDisk, PhotoRec) if CHKDSK cannot repair files.
step_5: Replace failing drives and restore data from backups when necessary.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: CHKDSK stuck - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

error_name: Slow disk response due to damaged areas
user_error_text: After a crash I now see: Slow disk response due to damaged areas on my drive.
symptoms: Symptoms: Slow disk response due to damaged areas. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Bad Sectors / Physical Disk Damage.
cause: Physical damage to disk sectors or NAND cell wear causing read/write failures.
step_1: Backup any accessible data immediately to another drive.
step_2: Run SMART diagnostic tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to check reallocated/pending sectors.
step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Slow disk response due to damaged areas - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: My system logs show: Drive shows 0 MB — how do I recover files?
symptoms: Symptoms: Drive shows 0 MB. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Partition Table & Volume Errors.
cause: Partition table corruption or accidental deletion leading to inaccessible volumes.
step_1: Open Disk Management to check partition status and flags.
step_2: If partition is missing, use TestDisk to attempt partition table recovery.
step_3: Avoid writing to the disk until recovery completes to prevent overwriting data.
step_4: If recovery fails, consider a professional data recovery service.
step_5: After recovery, repartition and format the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Drive shows 0 MB - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: File record segment unreadable appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: File record segment unreadable. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: File System Corruption Errors.
cause: Corrupted file system due to unsafe ejects, power loss, or disk errors.
step_1: Do not format immediately. Try safely reconnecting the drive to the PC.
step_2: Run Command Prompt as admin and use: `chkdsk X: /f /r` (replace X: with drive letter).
step_3: If CHKDSK cannot run, use data recovery tools (TestDisk, Recuva) to recover files first.
step_4: After recovering data, reformat the drive and run full disk checks.
step_5: Replace the drive if repeated corruption occurs; maintain regular backups.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: File record segment unreadable - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: Large file copies failing appears and files are not accessible.
symptoms: Symptoms: Large file copies failing. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Disk Full / Low Storage Issues.
cause: Insufficient free space causing system and application failures.
step_1: Free up space by removing large unused files and emptying Recycle Bin.
step_2: Use Disk Cleanup and Storage Sense to remove temp and system files.
step_3: Move large media files to external storage to free C: space.
step_4: Uninstall unnecessary programs and clean application caches.
step_5: Consider upgrading to a larger drive or adding a secondary disk.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Large file copies failing - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: Bad sectors found — when I try to open the drive it fails.
symptoms: Symptoms: Bad sectors found. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Bad Sectors / Physical Disk Damage.
cause: Physical damage to disk sectors or NAND cell wear causing read/write failures.
step_1: Backup any accessible data immediately to another drive.
step_2: Run SMART diagnostic tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to check reallocated/pending sectors.
step_3: Attempt `chkdsk /r` to remap bad sectors and recover readable data.
step_4: If sector count increases, plan to replace the drive as failure is imminent.
step_5: Use vendor utilities for SSD/HDD to run deeper firmware checks and diagnostics.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: Bad sectors found - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.

user_error_text: I get: EFI partition damaged and Windows asks me to format the disk.
symptoms: Symptoms: EFI partition damaged. Drive inaccessible, read/write errors, or system warnings. Category: Boot Sector / MBR / GPT Errors.
cause: Damaged MBR/GPT or boot record preventing OS from finding boot files.
step_1: Boot from Windows installation media and choose Repair → Command Prompt.
step_2: Run: `bootrec /fixmbr`, `bootrec /fixboot`, `bootrec /scanos`, `bootrec /rebuildbcd`.
step_3: If EFI partition is damaged, repair using `diskpart` and recreate the EFI partition as needed.
step_4: Verify BIOS/UEFI boot mode matches the partition table (MBR vs GPT).
step_5: If boot records cannot be restored, reinstall Windows after backing up data.
verification: Drive becomes accessible or data recovered; no further read/write errors reported.
log_snippet: EFI partition damaged - Storage diagnostic or SMART event logged.
